awd_titl_txt: A Digital Nudge: Assessing the Impact of an Immutable Records Data Management Platform on Student Researcher Ethics
awd_abstract_narration:
Many research projects involve scientists working in multiple research groups at several laboratories or universities. Quite often, project participants do not have access to the complete chain of data and information for a given project. As a result, mistakes and improper research conduct cannot be discovered and corrected by the project participants. Even if access to the data in the chain of events is provided, there may be lingering doubts about the veracity of the data, i.e., fears regarding the possibility that data was fabricated, improperly altered or that important information about data acquisition and processing steps were omitted. The consequence is that poor or misleading scientific studies can result in erroneous conclusions. Several recommendations have been promulgated to address the credibility of government-funded scientific studies, such as the report regarding reproducibility and replicability issued by the National Economic Council. The need to improve the credibility and replicability of scientific studies is closely related to the need for improving compliance with ethics and responsible research standards in academic and other research institutions. The objective of this project is to study and evaluate the potential of a Data Management Platform (DMP) for immutable research records to improve the ethics surrounding scientific research cultures and norms in university laboratory settings. Understanding how the management of immutable research records impacts the performance of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) student researchers is a crucial determinant to the success of the innovation challenge. An intermediate goal of this examination is to determine the extent to which the knowledge of a DMP enhances research standards. The overarching hypothesis is that a DMP will not only improve compliance with ethical and responsible conduct of research, it will also enhance the behaviors of student researchers toward the importance of data ethics as well as supplement ethics training they might receive through their institution. 
 
This project will establish a prototype for maintaining the transparency of research data through two mechanisms: (a) embedding technology into the scientific workflow (a ‘digital nudge’) in order to create cultures of ethically responsible research, and (b) evaluating the importance of mandatory compliance with research integrity standards. Evaluating the efficacy of the intervening DMP will be in the context of research-active environments such that STEM student researchers will be able to manage project originality and advances with time stamps on project data, ideas and discoveries. This evaluation will contribute to the theory of how motivation and social cognition influence behaviors toward research conduct. The dynamic updating of research progress with immutable recording in real-time will be with encrypted access and validation. In a comparative approach, surveys will be deployed to collect data from student researchers prior to and after the use of the DMP. The research design will employ a novel repeated analysis of variance (ANOVA) approach on the treatment group before and after the DMP intervention over two or more different time periods. The transformative agenda is the design to evaluate the extent to which immutable research records influence research innovation with pathways to new frontiers on ethics and responsible conduct of research. A key impact of this project will be ethics infused with equity because the absence of identity distinctions at the human-technology interface offers an avenue to not only accommodate student and faculty STEM researchers, but also proffers an inclusive ecosystem for equitable research responsibility and progress. Thus, this project will recruit underrepresented minorities and woman-identifying students in the study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Project Title: A Digital Nudge: Assessing the Impact of an Immutable Records Data Management Platform on Student Researcher Ethics

Synopsis: The Digital Nudge Project was an initiative aimed at understanding the impact of immutable research records on research ethics among STEM university students. With the rise of digital tools in scientific research, ensuring data integrity and ethical research practices has become crucial. This project explored whether the implementation of a Data Management Platform (DMP) that employs blockchain-inspired immutability principles can influence researchers' ethical behaviors at both the individual and institutional levels.

Project Goals and Implementation: The primary objective was to determine whether maintaining immutable research records fosters a culture of ethical research conduct. The study was structured around two key questions:

  1. To what extent does the introduction of immutable research records impact scientific ethics, given that researchers are aware of such record-keeping?
  2. How does the efficacy of an intervention such as a mandatory DMP influence research ethics at individual and laboratory levels?

To address these questions, a prototype DMP was developed, allowing students to store encrypted identifiers for unique versions of their research data while tracking changes through unique digital hashes (without the requirement to transfer the data itself). This tool was tested across multiple research labs in two universities, engaging over 20 STEM student researchers over three years. The project also incorporated surveys, advisory board discussions, and academic publications to validate findings.

Project Activities and Methodology: The project was carried out in three phases over three years:

  1. Development and Deployment of the DMP: The first year focused on the design and implementation of the DMP, which provided a secure platform for students to upload research records in a tamper-proof manner.
  2. Recruitment and Engagement: Participants were recruited from two universities, representing various STEM disciplines, including Biomedical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Systems Engineering. They were onboarded onto the platform and trained in its use.
  3. Assessment and Data Collection: Surveys were administered before and after the intervention to assess changes in ethical awareness. Additional qualitative data were gathered from faculty members and laboratory managers through interviews.

Key Findings and Outcomes: The following five areas demonstrate the impact avenues of the research including the key findings.

  1. Development and Implementation of the Data Management Platform (DMP): The platform provided a simple graphical user interface (GUI) for researchers to upload and hash their research files without storing actual data. This feature ensured security while fostering transparency. The platform supported encrypted identifiers for files up to 20GB and allowed unique identification of each data version.
  2. Behavioral Changes Among Participants: The project observed a shift in lab culture, with students reporting increased awareness and discussions about ethical research practices. Statistical analyses showed that lab supervisors and peers were more likely to encourage ethics training after implementing the DMP. Survey results indicated that discussions about ethical research practices became more frequent after implementation.
  3. Institutional and Individual Impact: Although no significant direct effect was found on students' ethical understanding, there was a marked improvement in attitudes toward data management and compliance with ethical standards. Additionally, students demonstrated changes in data storage behaviors, opting for more secure and structured approaches.
  4. Research Contributions: A systematic review paper examining research ethics in STEM education titled, “Research Ethics in STEM Education at Universities: A Scoping Review,” was published in the Journal of Academic Ethics. Additionally, the project's findings were accepted for presentation at the 2025 American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) conference. The research contributes to ongoing discussions on open science, transparency, and ethical best practices.
  5. Training and Professional Development: A research ethics training module was developed and delivered to all participants to supplement the intervention. The module covered responsible data handling, best practices in research integrity, and the ethical implications of immutable data management.

Conclusions and Implications: The results suggest that the introduction of immutable research records can positively influence research culture by promoting better data practices. While the direct impact on ethical understanding was inconclusive, the study demonstrated that structured interventions could drive behavioral changes in research environments.

The introduction of immutable research records improved general lab culture and increased peer encouragement for ethics training. Researchers were more likely to discuss ethical concerns openly, and some changed their data management approaches. However, the results highlight the need for more comprehensive training and policy integration to maximize the benefits of immutable record-keeping.

Future research should explore broader applications of such platforms, including potential policy recommendations for research institutions. There is also potential for interdisciplinary collaboration to further refine the approach and assess its scalability across different scientific disciplines.

The Digital Nudge Project has laid the groundwork for further exploration into digital interventions for research ethics, reinforcing the need for innovative solutions to maintain scientific integrity in an evolving research landscape.
